data.title: The Grecophone Byzantine Culture among the Melkites of the Late Middle Ages
data.abstractNote: The article is dedicated to survival of the Byzantine cultural heritage among the Middle Eastern Greek Orthodox community (the Melkites) from the late 14th till the early 16th cent. It was a period of isolation and “orientalization” of the Middle Eastern Patriarchates. However, several zones of contacts between various Greek Orthodox peoples were still preserved, first of all the Sinai monastery of St. Catherine, Jerusalem, the Judean desert monasteries, etc. The author analyzes the degree of spread of the Greek language and Greek liturgy in the Patriarchates of Jerusalem, Alexandria and Antioch in the late Mamluk period. Particular attention is paid to the autographs of the Patriarchs and other clerics, especially their Greek signatures as well as to the circulation of Greek and bilingual Greek-Arabic books in the Late Medieval Middle East.
